{{Infobox football derby | name = Le Classique | other names = Derby de France | image = [[File:Om-psg-2006-scarf.JPG|250px]] | caption = | city or region = [[Paris]] / [[Marseille]], [[France]] | first contested = 12 December 1971 | teams involved = [[Olympique de Marseille|Olympique Marseille]]
[[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] | most wins = [[Olympique de Marseille|Olympique Marseille]] (32) | mostrecent = [[Olympique de Marseille|OM]] 3 – 0 [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|PSG]] (27/11/11) | largestvictory = [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|PSG]] 5 – 1 [[Olympique de Marseille|OM]] (8/1/1978) }} '''Le Classique''' ({{IPA-fr|lÉ klasik}}, The Classic),{{cite news | title = Second time lucky as Marseille face PSG in Ligue 1's Le Classique | url = http://www.101greatgoals.com/second-time-lucky-as-marseille-face-psg-in-ligue-1s-le-classique/41027/ | work = 101 Great Goals | date = 19 November 2009 | accessdate = 23 April 2010}} also known as '''Derby de France''',{{cite news | title = Ligue 1 Preview: Paris Saint-Germain â Olympique de Marseille | url = http://goal.com/en/news/90/france/2010/02/26/1808160/ligue-1-preview-paris-saint-germain-olympique-de-marseille | work = [[Goal.com]] | date = 26 February 2010 | accessdate = 28 February 2010}} is a [[Association football|football]] match contested between [[France|French]] [[Ligue 1|top-flight]] clubs [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]] and [[Olympique de Marseille]]. The term "Le Classique" is modeled on the [[El ClÃ¡sico]], contested between [[Real Madrid C.F|Real Madrid]] and [[F.C. Barcelona|Barcelona]]. These meetings became important during the late [[1980s]] and the beginning of the [[1990s]]. [[Canal +]] and [[Bernard Tapie]] started to promote near the general public confrontations between the two clubs, making these matches of interest for all French football fans.{{cite news | title = Rewind to 1993: The shame of Marseille | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/columns/story/_/id/894439/rewind-to-1993:-the-shame-of-marseille?cc=3888 | work = [[ESPNsoccernet]] | date = 10 March 2011 | accessdate = 8 October 2011}} The tension between OM and PSG fans is legendary, and both clubs' world-class stadia, the [[Stade VÃ©lodrome]] and the [[Parc des Princes]], respectively, are renowned for the white-hot atmosphere and fervent fans. More and more, the various groups of Marseille and Parisian supporters have hated and battled each other. Important security measures are taken to prevent confrontations between the fans, but violent episodes still often occur every time the duo meet.{{cite news | title = OM-PSG D-2: The match that divides a nation | url = http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/om-psg-d-2-the-match-that-divides-a-nation.htm | work = [[Ligue 1]] | date = 23 October 2009 | accessdate = 25 October 2009}} Like all major rivalries, the antipathy between Paris Saint-Germain and Olympique de Marseille extends outside the pitch as [[Paris]] and [[Marseille]] are the two largest cities in [[France]], while the duo are the most successful and influential football clubs in the country having won eleven Ligue 1 titles, eighteen [[Coupe de France|French Cups]], five [[Coupe de la Ligue|League Cups]] and five [[TrophÃ©e des Champions|Champions Trophy]]. Both clubs are also the only French clubs to have won a major European trophy, as PSG claimed the [[UEFA Cup Winners' Cup]] in [[1995â96 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup|1996]] and OM landed the [[UEFA Champions League]] in [[1992â93 UEFA Champions League|1993]]. The duo were the dominant forces before the appearance of [[Olympique Lyonnais]] during the 21st century. Despite their recent ups and downs, PSG and OM remain, along with [[AS Saint-Ãtienne|Saint-Ãtienne]], the only French clubs with a truly nationwide, faithful and passionate fan base, giving the country's biggest match a special atmosphere.{{cite news | title = France's passion play | url = http://www.fifa.com/classicfootball/stories/classicderby/news/newsid=1037223.html#frances+passion+play | work = [[FIFA]] | accessdate = 25 October 2009}} ==History== {{Main|History of Le Classique}} [[File:OM PSG TROPHEE DES CHAMPIONS.jpg|210px|right|thumb|OM won the [[2010 TrophÃ©e des Champions|Supercup]] against PSG.]] The so-called "French clÃ¡sico" has a historical, cultural and social importance that makes it more than a simple football game, facing capital against province and the chosen ones of French football against their "enfants terribles". The match is often referred to as the North versus the South as the duo represent [[Paris]], the national capital, and [[Marseille]], the chief city of southern [[France]]. Many French people dislike Paris due to its dominant political, cultural and economic influence. By extension, they tend to dislike its chief football team, Paris Saint-Germain, mainly supported by Parisians. As the best-supported club, Olympique de Marseille also attracts its share of detractors. The rivalry may not be the oldest in France's top flight, but it is undoubtedly the fiercest and most significant both on and off the pitch, being a fixture that divides loyalties right around the country. It is the most followed football match in France, watched by millions of people in the country. The southerners have been around for over a century now, while "Les Parisiens" only came into being in 1970, and in their early meetings there was little indication the two would become deadly adversaries as the situation between both clubs were two worlds apart. Meetings between the duo became relevant during [[1988â89 Division 1|1988â1989]]. PSG and OM faced each other in a virtual title decider at the [[Stade VÃ©lodrome]], with both clubs tied on points. [[Franck SauzÃ©e]] scored a last minute winner giving OM the title. 1993 saw Marseille reached both the very pinnacle and the very bottom of the European club game. A corruption scandal and a Canal+'s shining light for Paris Saint-Germain would threaten their hegemony. [[Basile Boli]] hit home the winning goal against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] as Marseille became the first French side to win a European trophy and the only to win the [[1992â93 UEFA Champions League|Champions League]]. Their fans greeted the triumph by chanting "A jamais les premiers" which referred to the fact that they won the first "Classico" against PSG in 1971. Three days later, Boli's 18-yard header against PSG gave Marseille their fifth straight [[Ligue 1]] title. The city exploded with a joy shared across the nation but no sooner had the trophy been hoist aloft than the celebrations were brought to a halt. It is believed that [[Bernard Tapie]] bribed [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]] to lose so that Marseille would win the French League earlier, giving them more time to prepare for the Champions League Final. Marseille was later stripped of their League title and relegated to Division 2 by the [[French Football Federation|FFF]], while Bernard Tapie was forced to step down as its President. Marseille would dominate the fixture for many years and from 1990 to 1999 they did not lose to their arch-rivals in the league. On 8 May 1996, Paris Saint-Germain became the youngest European club to win a European Cup, doing so in its 26th year. Driven by French playmaker [[Youri Djorkaeff]], PSG became the second and last French club to win a European title, beating [[Rapid Wien]] in the [[1996 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup Final|Cup Winners' Cup Final]] thanks to [[Bruno N'Gotty]]'s indirect free kick. [[Luis FernÃ¡ndez]] became the first and, so far only, French manager to win a major European trophy. Paris Saint-Germain then earned their first league win over their arch-rivals since 1990. Olympique de Marseille would finish the season a point behind champions Bordeaux making the victory even more special for the capital club. PSG became the dominant side, achieving eight consecutive wins between 2002 and 2004. Paris won all the three matches disputed in 2003, including two wins at the VÃ©lodrome, with superlatives performances from [[Ronaldinho]]. Six more victories arrived for PSG thanks in part to [[Pauleta]]'s goals. He scored 6 times in 11 appearances, becoming Le Classique's all-time top scorer. The two met in the [[2006 Coupe de France Final|French Cup Final]] in 2006. PSG was struggling to avoid relegation, while OM was looking for a spot in Europe. PSG, however, lifted the French Cup for the seventh time in their history thanks to a magnficent 25-yard-goal from [[Vikash Dhorasoo]]. PSG then recorded their first victory at the VÃ©lodrome since 2004, but Marseille responded with their biggest ever win and their first back-to-back victories at the Parc des Princes.{{cite news | title = Record win for OM at PSG | url = http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/record-win-for-om-at-psg.htm | work = [[Ligue 1]] | date = 28 February 2010 | accessdate = 28 February 2010}} These victories set "Les Marsellais" on the road to their ninth [[2009â10 Ligue 1|Ligue 1]] title, having already clinched their first [[2009â10 Coupe de la Ligue|League Cup]].{{cite news | title = Marseille wins 9th French League title | url = http://www.cbc.ca/sports/soccer/story/2010/05/05/sp-french-league-title.html | work = [[CBC Sports]] | date = 5 May 2010 | accessdate = 5 May 2010}} PSG, meanwhile, repaid their fans after a tough season with their eighth [[2009â10 Coupe de France|French Cup]] to ensure a return to European competition.{{cite news | title = Hoarau saves PSG's season! | url = http://www.ligue1.com/autresCompetitions/article/hoarau-saves-psg-s-season.htm | work = [[Ligue 1]] | date = 1 May 2010 | accessdate = 3 May 2010}} Olympique de Marseille then defeated PSG for a fourth consecutive match after [[Edouard CissÃ©]] struck the winning penalty against his former club as the Ligue 1 champions lifted the [[2010 TrophÃ©e des Champions]].{{Cite news | title = CissÃ© wins Champions Trophy for Marseille in shootout | url = http://www.ligue1.com/tropheeChampions/article/cisse-wins-champions-trophy-for-marseille-in-shootout.htm | work = [[Ligue 1]] | date = 28 July 2010 | accessdate = 28 July 2010}} ==Incidents== PSG's former owners [[Canal+]], knowing the significance it could take on in the French socio-sporting landscape, began to promote confrontations between the two sides in the early [[1990s]]. OM's infamous former president [[Bernard Tapie]] also claims he instigated and nurtured the rivalry to motivate his team since the late [[1980s]]. More and more, the numerous groups of Marseille and Paris supporters have hated and battled each other. Important security measures are taken to prevent confrontations. However, many incidents still occur between the supporters when both clubs clash. * '''11 April 1995''' : 146 arrests and 9 policemen hospitalized due to fighting in the semi-final of the [[Coupe de France]].{{cite news | title = Marseille plan to take advanatge of poorly PSG in Ligue 1's Le Classique | url = http://www.101greatgoals.com/marseille-plan-to-take-advanatge-of-poorly-psg-in-ligue-1s-le-classique/39206/ | work = 101 Great Goals | date = 22 October 2009 | accessdate = 6 October 2011}} * '''12 October 1999''' : a bus was inflamed.{{cite news | title = Contrat Local de SÃ©curitÃ© pour le Parc des Princes (2004) | url = http://www.paris.fr/accueil/Portal.lut?page_id=8684&document_type_id=4&document_id=54902&portlet_id=20594&multileveldocument_sheet_id=10254 | work = Paris.fr | date = 29 June 2010 | accessdate = 6 October 2011}} * '''13 October 2000''' : an 18-year-old Marseille supporter was paralyzed for life after being struck by a seat thrown from the Parisians section of the [[Parc des Princes]]. * '''10 February 2002''' : a 16-year-old Marseille fan was half decapitated (his head was out the window of a moving bus when it slammed into a bridge abutment); a Parisian fan suffered a broken arm after falling into the ditch that separates the turn Auteuil from the lawn; 15 arrests; 2 provisional detentions; several vehicles damaged; a fire inside the Parc des Princes.{{cite news | title = PSG-OM : tout un quartier sur le pied de guerre | url = http://www.ladepeche.fr/article/2002/10/25/402119-PSG-OM-tout-un-quartier-sur-le-pied-de-guerre.html | work = [[La DÃ©pÃªche du Midi]] | date = 25 October 2002 | accessdate = 6 October 2011}} * '''26 October 2002''' : 61 arrests.{{cite news | title = Quinze ans d'Ã©chauffourÃ©es | ISSN = 0767-3558 | work = [[Le Parisien]] | date = 19 December 2008 | accessdate = 8 October 2011}} * '''25 January 2003''' : 43 arrests. * '''9 March 2003''' : 27 injured; 1 hospitalized. * '''29 April 2006''' : 2 injured for clashes in the vicinity of the [[Stade de France]]. * '''2 September 2007''' : 5 arrests; 3 injured. * '''15 March 2009''' : 22 arrests; 9 provisional detentions.{{cite news | title = PSG-OM : 22 individus arrÃªtÃ©s par la police | url = http://www.maxifoot.fr/football-rss93649/psg-om.php | work = Maxifoot | date = 16 March 2009 | accessdate = 8 October 2011}} * '''25 October 2009''' : 10 arrests; 10 injured (a PSG supporter was hit by a car which then fled).{{cite news | title = Violence in Marseille After Game Postponed | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2009/10/27/sports/soccer/27iht-SOCCER.html | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 26 October 2009 | accessdate = 28 October 2009}} * '''20 November 2009''' : 15 arrests.{{cite news | title = Marseille beats PSG 1â0; 15 fans arrested | url = http://thestar.com.my/sports/story.asp?file=/2009/11/21/sports/20091121085608&sec=sports | work = [[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] | date = 21 November 2009 | accessdate = 24 November 2009}} * '''28 February 2010''' : 20 arrests; Boulogne Boys member Yann L. was left in a life-threatening coma after being attacked by another PSG group, the Supras Auteuil.{{cite news | title = Coupet: PSG squad "responsible" for OM violence | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=750159&sec=europe&cc=3888 | work = [[ESPNsoccernet]] | date = 3 March 2010 | accessdate = 3 March 2010}} * '''18 March 2010''' : Yann L. died in the hospital after being in a coma since 28 February.{{cite news | title = PSG fan dies after attack from fellow supporters | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=757618&sec=europe&cc=3888 | work = [[ESPNsoccernet]] | date = 18 March 2010 | accessdate = 22 March 2010}} ==Other Facts== According to a survey by [[Le Point]] in 2009, Olympique de Marseille has the largest following in France with 20%. Paris Saint-Germain, tied with [[Olympique Lyonnais]], is far behind with 11%. [[FC Girondins de Bordeaux|Girondins de Bordeaux]] is close behind with 10%.{{cite news | title = L'OM, Ã©quipe de football prÃ©fÃ©rÃ©e des FranÃ§ais | url = http://www.lepoint.fr/actualites-societe/2009-08-07/sondage-ifop-l-om-equipe-de-football-preferee-des-francais/920/0/367474 | work = [[Le Point]] | date = 7 August 2009 | accessdate = 30 September 2009}} Marseille are also the most popular French club in the world followed by Paris and Lyon.{{cite news | title = Top European Football Clubs Have Global Fan Base | url = http://www.comscore.com/Press_Events/Press_Releases/2007/05/European_Football_Clubs | work = [[comScore]] | date = 15 May 2007 | accessdate = 30 October 2009}} Paris Saint-Germain hold the honor of being the richest club in the country and are one of the richest clubs in the world.{{cite news | title = Beckham poised to sign with French side | url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/soccer-football/news/article.cfm?c_id=86&objectid=10761591 | work = [[The New Zealand Herald]] | date = 25 October 2011 | accessdate = 9 November 2011}} OM are the third richest club in France, only surpassed by Lyon.{{cite news | title = PSG, OL, OM, ASSEâ¦: Les effectifs les plus chers de L1 | url = http://www.sportune.fr/sport-business/psg-ol-om-asse%E2%80%A6-les-effectifs-les-plus-chers-de-l1-35529 | work = Sportune.fr | date = 9 September 2011 | accessdate = 12 September 2011}} The duo were founding members of the [[G-14]] and form part of its modern replacement, the [[European Club Association]]. OM's average home gate for the [[2010â11 Ligue 1|2010â11]] season was 51,081, the highest in the Ligue 1, while PSG came fourth with 29,317.{{cite news | title = Attendances 2010/11 | url = http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/affluences/club | work = [[Ligue 1]] | accessdate = 1 June 2011}} PSG was named [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics|IFFHS World's Club Team of the Year]] in [[1994 in association football|1994]] and ranked 1st in the [[UEFA coefficient|UEFA Team Ranking]] in [[1998 in association football|1998]]. Paris Saint-Germain is the only French club to ever achieve these honours.{{cite news | title = IFFHS Club World Ranking 1994 | url = http://www.iffhs.de/?eedbca388d8569d817285fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70a21c | work = [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics|IFFHS]] | accessdate = 12 October 2010}}{{cite news | title = UEFA Team Ranking 1998 | url = http://www.xs4all.nl/~kassiesa/bert/uefa/data/method1/trank1998.html | work = [[XS4ALL]] | accessdate = 12 October 2010}} Marseille reached the 3rd spot in 1991, their highest since the creation of the ranking.{{cite news | title = IFFHS Club World Ranking 1991 | url = http://www.iffhs.de/?eedbca388d8569d817285fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70a713 | work = [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics|IFFHS]] | accessdate = 12 October 2010}} From 1993 to 1997, PSG finished in the top ten of the Club World Raking. The IFFHS also publishes a ranking taking into account the results over the past twelve months. PSG has been five times 1st in this mensual rankings.{{cite news | title = Clubs more times First in Club World Ranking | url = http://www.iffhs.de/?bca384f02788705f94b40385fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70aeed412 | work = [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics|IFFHS]] | accessdate = 12 October 2010}} Taking into account the period from 1991 to 2009, PSG is ranked 25th globally, being the highest ranked French club after Lyon.{{cite news | title = All-Time Club World Ranking | url = http://www.iffhs.de/?3d4d443d0b803e8b40384c00205fdcdc3bfcdc0aec70aeedbe1a | work = [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics|IFFHS]] | accessdate = 12 October 2010}} PSG and OM are currently ranked 12th and 51st in the IFFHS.{{cite news | title = IFFHS Club World Ranking | url = http://www.iffhs.de/?10f42e00fa2d17f73702fa3016e23c17f7370eff3702bb1c2bbb6f28f53512 | work = [[International Federation of Football History & Statistics|IFFHS]] | date = 30 September 2010 | accessdate = 12 October 2010}} The duo, meanwhile, are respectively ranked 47th and 17th in the UEFA Team Ranking.{{cite news | title = UEFA Team Ranking 2012 | url = http://kassiesa.home.xs4all.nl/bert/uefa/data/method4/trank2012.html | work = [[XS4ALL]] | date = 22 July 2011 | accessdate = 22 July 2011}} ==Statistics== :''{{As of|2011|11|27}}.'' {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" style="font-size: 90%; margin:0px;" width="100%" ! colspan="6" style="text-align:center;" |Titles |- || {|width=100% border="2" cellpadding="4" style="border-collapse:collapse; text-align:center;" |- style="background:#f0f6ff;" ! style="color:red; background:#022662;" colspan=6|Paris Saint-Germain |- ! Total ! 77 !! 26 !! 92 !! 19 !! 32 !! 102 |} |- |} ==Switching Sides== 47 players have worn the shirt of both Olympique Marseille and Paris Saint-Germain. Sometimes through a direct transfer, sometimes after many years and some have even found their way back. The number increases to 49 if we add [[Carlos Abel da Silva Braga|Abel Braga]], who played for PSG from 1979 to 1981 and then managed OM in 2000, and [[Tomislav IviÄ]], who managed both Paris and Marseille. The large amount of players who have represented for both sides is surprisingly high considering the enmity between the clubs. Olympique Marseille's current squad features former Paris Saint-Germain players [[Ãdouard CissÃ©]], [[Fabrice Abriel]] and [[Gabriel Heinze]]. Paris Saint-Germain, meanwhile, have former Marseille members [[PÃ©guy Luyindula]] and [[Claude MakÃ©lÃ©lÃ©]]. An incredible surprise for many supporters, as it seems obvious that a player from Marseille has nothing to do in Paris and viceversa, especially when there isn't a 10-year-career in between. Only four players have left one club for the other and then returned. [[JÃ©rÃ´me Leroy (footballer)|JÃ©rÃ´me Leroy]] left Paris Saint-Germain in 1999 for Olympique Marseille and then returned to the French capital in 2002. [[Xavier Gravelaine]], meanwhile, left Paris Saint-Germain in 1995 to join [[En Avant de Guingamp|Guingamp]] before signing for Marseille in 1996. Three years later, he returned to Paris. [[Bruno Germain]] was directly transferred from Marseille to Paris Saint-Germain in 1991. He returned to the south of France in 1994. [[Saar Boubacar]] had the same experience, arriving at the capital club from Olympique Marseille in 1979 before returning to his first club in 1983. The rivalry has never prevented the business. Many players have crossed the bridge without knowing or caring about the intense rivalry between both clubs and have subsequently suffered abuses from the supporters.{{cite news | title = Les joueurs qui ont connu le PSG et lâOM | url = http://www.psgmag.net/409-28e-j-Les-joueurs-qui-ont-connu-le-PSG-et-l | work = PSGMAG.NET | date = 12 March 2009 | accessdate = 3 February 2011}} Love and passion for the shirt is a figment of the imagination and career choices from the players have ended in sounded failures. Captain [[FrÃ©dÃ©ric DÃ©hu]] left Paris Saint-Germain, [[2003â04 Ligue 1|Ligue 1]] vice-champions, [[2003â04 Coupe de France|French Cup]] champions and [[2004â05 UEFA Champions League|UEFA Champions League]] contenders, for an Olympique de Marseille side without European action but that would pay him twice the amount he earned at the capital club in 2004. His future was revealed just days before the [[2004 Coupe de France Final|French Cup Final]] against [[LB ChÃ¢teauroux|ChÃ¢teauroux]] and he was widely booed by Paris fans throughout the match. After the final whistle, DÃ©hu run to the locker room to hide his tears before coming out and briefly lifting the trophy.{{cite news | title = DÃ©hu : "La faute du PSG" | url = http://www.eurosport.fr/football/coupe-de-france-04/2003-2004/dehu-la-faute-du-psg_sto595367/story.shtml | work = [[Eurosport]] | date = 30 May 2004 | accessdate = 28 October 2009}} Months later, [[Fabrice FiorÃ¨se]] slammed the door at PSG after a confrontation with then manager [[Vahid HalilhodÅ¾iÄ]]. He was transferred to OM in stormy conditions and went from being a fan favorite to being the most hated. Considered to be the new [[Christophe Dugarry]] at the time, FiorÃ¨se insisted on the fact that HalilhodÅ¾iÄ had refused his request to miss a match when his wife gave birth. A player's transferring directly from one club to another is seen as high treason, as Fabrice FiorÃ¨se discovered when he was effectively whistled and chanted out of a Clasico by Paris fans outraged by his transfer to their arch-rivals. "Treason" has in fact happened in different ways: transfers, players out of contract or exchange. During the [[1990s]], we witnessed the record shuffles between the two cities, when the sporting and media rivalry was at its peak. French football hope [[Jocelyn Angloma]] from PSG was exchanged for OM players [[Bernard Pardo]], [[Bruno Germain]] and [[Laurent Fournier]]. Laurent Fournier replaced Vahid HalilhodÅ¾iÄ as PSG coach and midfielder [[Lorik Cana]] fell out of favour in 2005. This prompted him to move to the south of France.
